awd_titl_txt: Methods and Applications for Optimization with Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
The  demand for  advanced  optimization software  tools is  increasing sharply as the importance  of optimization methodology in engineering, basic  science,  finance and  data  science  is becoming  more  widely recognized.  The  dramatic  increase   in  computing  power,  and  the improvements in supporting technologies such as modeling languages and automatic   differentiation  are   fueling  demand   for  optimization algorithms  that  solve  more  and  more  computationally  challenging problems, including nonlinear  optimization problems with differential equation constraints and/or discrete  variables.  This project focuses on several  fundamental computational issues involved  in the parallel implicit solution of optimization  problems with differential equation constraints.  Such problems arise in  many contexts in engineering and scientific  computation, since  physical  reality  is often  expressed through models involving ordinary  and partial differential equations. Accurate discretizations of differential  equation constraints lead to very large structured constrained optimization problems, where much of the  structure reflects  the discretization.  A specific  goal is  the development   of   modern   algorithms   that   are   well-suited   to implementation  on advanced  computing platforms  (such as  those with multicore and GPU  architectures), interoperable with high-performance software  in  related areas  (such  as  linear algebra),  and  readily customizable for  particular important applications.  A  major part of the project involves the development of software and its dissemination within  the  manufacturing,   engineering  and  scientific  community. Software developed  as part of  the project will provide  an effective method  of  technology   transfer  and  will  extend   the  scope  and effectiveness of the  existing codes PLTMG, MC and  SNOPT developed by the investigators.  

Differential equations conveniently characterize  the physical laws of many complex systems  occurring in science and  engineering. They also lie  at the  heart of  the mathematical  models used  to simulate  and predict  the behavior  of these  systems.   The need  to optimize  the performance  of  such  systems  is the  common  feature  of  practical applications that range over such diverse areas as the design of large neurobiological   network   models,    the   numerical   modeling   of gravitational  waves,  and  trajectory  planning  for  spacecraft  and unmanned  autonomous vehicles  (UAVs).  Software  developed under  the auspices of  this project will  provide engineers and  scientists with instant  access  to  state-of-the-art  methods for  the  modeling  and optimization  of  complex   systems  involving  differential  equation constraints.  The  resulting improvements in the  efficiency, accuracy and robustness of these models will have a substantial impact in areas of  manufacturing  and  engineering  that   are  vital  to  US  global competitiveness.

por.por_cntn:
This project has involved a program of research on several fundamental computational issues involved in the parallel implicit solution of optimization problems with differential equation constraints.  Such problems arise in many contexts in engineering and scientific computation, since physical reality is often expressed through models involving ordinary and partial differential equations (ODEs and PDEs).  Accurate discretizations of differential equation constraints lead to very large sparse constrained optimization problems, where much of the structure reflects the discretization.

The research has advanced the state-of-the-art in several respects.  In the area of optimization, advanced new methods and software have been formulated and analyzed for the solution of challenging large-scale nonlinearly constrained problems with differential equation constraints.  Research has focused of the crucial role of regularization and stabilization in the formulation and analysis of modern sequential quadratic programming (SQP) and interior methods, which are generally considered to be the best general-purpose methods for nonlinear optimization.  Regularization and stabilization are vital tools for resolving the numerical and theoretical difficulties associated with ill-posed or degenerate problems.  Broadly speaking, regularization involves perturbing the problem so that a well-defined solution always exists.  Stabilization is designed to provide practical methods that can rapidly and reliably compute the solution of the problem.  New regularized and stabilized SQP and interior methods have been developed and applied to a number of practical applications involving differential equation constraints, including the calculation of the optimal trajectories of a space craft, the optimal cooling of a jet engine, the time-optimal control of a vehicle transporting a fluid container, and the construction of subcellular diffusion maps based on bio­imaging data,

In the area of partial differential equations, much of our effort was focused on efficiently integrating adaptivity and parallelization into the PDE constrained optimization framework. Adaptivity typically involves a so-called adaptive feedback loop.  Here the problem is solved using a small approximation space, and its solution is used to assemble a-posteriori error estimates. These in turn are used to enlarge the approximation space through local refinement of the mesh or increasing the local order of the approximation space. The problem is then solved on this enriched space, and the process is repeated until a sufficiently accurate solution is obtained. This process raised several important issues: (i) how accurately do the intermediate problems in the feedback loop need to be solved? (ii) what are efficient solvers for these systems? (iii) what are effective techniques for computing a-posteriori error estimates in this context? (iv) based on these error estimates how does one decide where and how to enrich the approximating subspace? Substantial progress was made on all of these issues during the period of the award.

As an example, parallel computation plays an increasingly important role here.  The largest PDE constrained optimization problems developed through adaptive feedback loops can have millions of unknowns: 200 million is the largest problem we have solved on our small parallel cluster, and industrial problems can easily be much larger. The efficient solution of such large problems requires iterative solvers specialized to the type of systems arising in this context.  In PDE constrained optimization, a crucial issue is that of ``warm starting'' the optimization process using as initial guess the solution generated on the previous step of the feedback loop. Distributing the workload among the processors is also challenging because the distribution of unknowns is created dynamically during the feedback loop. These issues have been successfully addressed.

Mathematical software is one of the most effective means of technology transfer.  Its wide distribution allows the latest algorithmic research to become rapidly available to practitioners in all relevant areas. The new methods developed under the auspices of this award are the basis of the software packages SQOPT, SNOPT, DNOPT and LRHB that have been made available to scientists and engineers in Industry, Academia and Government.  The finite element package PLTMG is freely available through Netlib, and includes options for solving several classes of PDE constrained optimization problems, incorporating algorithms for adaptivity and parallel computation developed under this award.
